bboxes.raw_text:
NEW YORK = Floyd Patterson.
the former heavyweight cham
pion from New York. was named
Fighter of the Month by Ring
Magaz zine for his l2-round de-
cision over contender Eddie Ma
chen of Los Angeles at Stockholm
recently.


In addition, Patterson was
boosted from seventh contender
to the No. 2 spot in the July ra-
tings by Ring. Machen was
dropped from fourth to seventh.
Doug Jones of New York, who
was ranked second. was denoted
to fourth because of inactivity.
Sonny Liston, the former champ
Ion from Denver. is No. |, and
Fora Foley of Chandler is third.

Patterson Is
Fighter OF
The Month

CHICAGO NPD Negro Press
Internationaps sports editor
Charles ]. Livingston points
a finger at the nation for failing
to give financial help to our
Olympic athletes.


He reviewed cases of John
Thomas, high jumper Hayes
Jones, ace hurdler and Ralph
Boston, top broad jumper. who
need money to support them
selves while in training.


Livingstons says that America
has great athletes and Congress
should subsidize them.

WASHINGTON Three South
ern governors. Orval Faubus OF
Arkansas, George Wallace OF
Alabama and Paul Johnson. OF
Mississippi. refused to meet with
Leroy Collins and accept as
.sistance from the newly formed
Community Relations Service
headed by him.


Collins has been unable to meet
with Governor Donald Russell OF
South Carolina. also.


President Johnson named
Collins, a former governor OF
Florida, to the dictatorship OF
the Community Relations Service
which was created by the civil
rights law.


Six southern governors have
agreed to meet with collins. They
represent the states of Florida,
Georgia, Louisiana. North Caro-
lima. Tennessee and Virginia.

Dixie Governors


Refuse To Meet
With Leroy Collins

model character of Uncle
Methodist minister after his thrilling
slavery Kentucky Canada He conducted hundreds of
fugitive escaping Kentucky through
Ohio.


Father Iensons Own Story he relates most thrilling
incidents with much interest Henson
considered his operations in connection with the Under
ground outstanding achievement of his Yet
founding the Manual Labor
Institute developing community in Southern Ontario. He
was appear before Queen Victoria for his community
establishment.

Frederick O'Neal, a veteran
Negro actor, was elected to the
presidency of the $4,000 member
Actors Equity Association in
May. 1864.


He succeeded Ralph Bellamy,
who held the post for IL years.
O'Nears victory marks the first
time a Negro has been elected
to such high post, though the
ST yr. old actors union has been
integrated for the past rs years.


The E #. 2 in. 220 FOUNDER
started in theatrical work In 1928.
Born in Brooksville, MISS,
Frederick's family moved to st.
Louis when he was IA. He con-
siders that city his home.


He said the Urban League Of
St. Louis provided his first OPP
portunity to act. He appeared in
Shakespeare's GAS You Like It."


He organized the Aldridge
Players, a community theater
group of dedicated Negro amateur
performers in St. Louis in 1927.


O'Neal ais founded the Ameri-
can Negro Theater in New York
City in 1910 and initiated and
assisted the organization of the
British Negro Theater in London
in l948.


He served with the armed for
ces with the 93rd Infantry Divi-
sion.


Audiences will remember him
as Frank in the stage and movie
productions of "Anna Lucasta".


He has an enviable career on
the stage, film. radio and tele-
vision. He has recorded recor-
ding series on Great American
Negroes and has appeared as
narrator with the NewY ork Phil
harmonic Orchestra.


An authority on the Negro in
the theater. Mr.. ONeal has pre-
scented many lectures thr oughout
the country and he has served as
a visiting professor at Southern
Illinois University and Clark Col
lege, Atlanta.


In 1896 he left St. Louis to try
his luck on Broadway. Success
did not come overnight, but he
kept studying and finally won
some good roles.


He has won several awards in
Guiding the Derwent Award. Cri-
tics Poll, Donalds on Award, Best
Actor of the Chicago Season and
the Canada Lee Award.

1918 A division of Negro
Economics was established In
the Depar tment of Labor to study
problems of Negro wage earners
as incidental to intensified war
time migration. 1t was discon-
tinued in 1922.

REM L. jennings recently resigned from Supreme Court
for the Democratic US Senate
his judicial robe for the party given
honor by his high colleagues few days ago.


Lending helping hand Justice Lorna Lockwood,
Mrs. Jennings eekng her husbands shouder) U.s.
Ambassador Ghana ahoney currently vacationng
in Arizona with his family.

GOSPORT, HAMPSHIRE,
ENGLAND-Soaring wall mu-
rails dominate these tall modern
apartment houses. The eye
catching murals can be seen for
miles around. The "arty" build
ings were erected as part of a
redevelopment scheme for the
area.
